importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Dina Boluarte was removed from office by Congress on this date after an impeachment, leading to the establishment of an interim government under Jose Jeri.
The state of emergency in Lima was officially declared on this day by interim President Jose Jeri, amid escalating protests and rising violence.
A previous state of emergency was declared by Dina Boluarte in March 2025 following the murder of singer Paul Flores, which highlighted the government’s failure to curb organized crime.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The state of emergency declared by Jose Jeri in Lima is set to last for 30 days, beginning on October 22, 2025, and will extend until November 21, 2025, pending further decisions.
Between January and September 2024, Peru reported 1,502 homicides, a baseline against which the increase to 1,690 in the same period in 2025 is measured.

keyTakeAways: Peru’s interim President Jose Jeri has declared a 30-day state of emergency in Lima to address violent protests driven by youth-led anti-government movements focused on corruption and organized crime.
The emergency allows the government to deploy the military, restrict freedom of assembly, and suspend constitutional rights, raising concerns about civil liberties.
Extortion cases have surged by 30% in 2025, reaching 18,000, with a corresponding rise in violence: 1,690 homicides reported between January and September 2025, compared to 1,502 in 2024.
The state of emergency follows the impeachment and removal of President Dina Boluarte on October 10, 2025, after Congress cited her inability to combat rising crime and corruption.
Protests in Lima turned violent on October 22, resulting in one death and around 100 injuries, including police and journalists, prompting Jeri to reaffirm his decision not to resign.
The previous state of emergency declared by Boluarte in March 2025 after the killing of singer Paul Flores failed to reduce crime, indicating a pattern of ineffective crisis response.

Al Jazeera’s Mariana Sanchez reported from Lima, noting that the new emergency decree does not specify how intelligence to combat extortion will be gathered, raising transparency and accountability concerns.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Peru’s interim President Jose Jeri has declared a 30-day state of emergency in the capital, Lima, following weeks of violent protests led by Gen-Z activists over corruption and organized crime. The emergency, which allows military deployment and curtailment of civil liberties, follows the impeachment and removal of President Dina Boluarte on October 10, 2025, after Congress accused her of failing to address a surge in extortion and violence. Extortion cases have risen by 30% to 18,000 this year, with 1,690 homicides reported between January and September 2025—up from 1,502 in 2024. The move has sparked criticism, especially given that a previous emergency under Boluarte in March 2025 failed to reduce crime. On October 22, protests turned violent, resulting in one death and over 100 injuries, including police and journalists. Jeri has affirmed he will not resign, despite pressure to step down.
title: State of emergency declared in Peru’s capital amid protests
